> Welcome to the **total.js documentation**. Total.js is free web application framework for building Web sites and Web applications using JavaScript, HTML and CSS. The framework has very simple logic, a short learning curve and many features for creating rich, scalable web applications.

## Installation options

I recommend download the framework with __empty project__:

- Install [node.js platform](http://www.nodejs.org) on your computer
- [Download empty project](https://github.com/totaljs/framework/releases)
- Unpack and run via terminal:

```bash
$ cd myapp
$ node debug.js
```

__Empty project__ contains 3x startup files `debug.js` (for development), `release.js` (for production) and `test.js` (for assertion testing). __IMPORTANT__: The startup file `debug.js` automatically watchs all changes in your project and after is created a change the script restarts the application automatically.

## Other ways for installation

### 1. NPM (Node package manager)

Node.js platform includes [Node package manager](http://www.npmjs.com) (NPM). This option install __total.js__ into current directory.

```bash
$ mkdir myapp
$ cd myapp
$ npm install total.js --save
```

### 2. NPM (Node package manager) installation as global module

If you install framework as global module you do not need to install framework to each web application. The global module contains executable (binary) file, this file contains many features (templates) for creating total.js applications.

```bash
$ sudo npm install -g total.js
```

__Try to write__ into the terminal or command-line after the installation:

```bash
$ total -help
```

### 3. Run the framework without installation

Create `index.js` filea and put below content into the file. Run it: `node index.js`.

```javascript
function main() {

    F.route('/', function() {
        this.plain('HOMEPAGE');
    });

    // debug (debug mode), release (release mode), test (test mode)
    F.http('debug');
}

require('http').get('http://modules.totaljs.com/total.js/v1.7.0/total.js', function(res) {
    var buffer = [];
    res.on('data', function(buf) { buffer.push(buf.toString('utf8')); });
    res.on('end', function() { eval(buffer.join('')); if (typeof(main) !== 'undefined') main(); });
});
```

### Read more:

- [Total.js - Tutorial](#pages~Tutorial)
- [Total.js - Directory structure](#pages~Directory%20structure)

> __Total.js__ project has a _simple directory structure_. All directories are optional and you can rewrite each path of directory in the framework configuration file.

## Directories

```markdown
controllers
databases
definitions
logs
models
modules
public
resources
source
packages
tests
tmp
views
workers
```

### Directory: controllers

Directory contains only controllers. In controller you can define routes with different actions. Controllers are __most important__ feature in the framework.

- [How do controllers work?](#pages~Controllers)

---

### Directory: databases

Directory contains __NoSQL embedded databases__ (if are). NoSQL database is a plain text file with serialized documents in JSON format. Some [3rd modules](https://github.com/totaljs/modules) store a small data in this directory.

- [How does NoSQL database work?](#pages~NoSQL)
- [Example: Database](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/contact-form)

---

### Directory: definitions

Directory contains all definitions. The definition defines behaviour of the framework. The definition is great for change a behaviour of e.g. modules.

- [How do definitions work?](#pages~Definitions)

---

### Directory: logs

Directory contains logs. Log file is plain text file. You can append a log message via `framework.log(message)` everywhere. Log filename is created by date.

- [Example: Logs](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/logs)

---

### Directory: models

Directory contains models. The model can contain functions or some [schemas](#api~Builders.SchemaBuilder). Recommended for database models.

- [How do models work?](#pages~Models)
- [Example: Models](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/models)

---

### Directory: modules

Directory contains extended modules. The module can create routes or can contain classes, functions or constants. You can download existing modules or you can create your own module.

- [How do modules work?](#pages~Modules)
- [Example: Modules](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/framework-modules)
- [Download 3rd modules](https://github.com/totaljs/modules)

---

### Directory: public

This directory is published directory and contains all static files (JavaScripts, CSS files, Pictures, Fonts, Documents, Videos, Uploads, etc.). Browser can get (almost) everything from the public directory.

---

### Directory: resources

If you create web pages that will be read by speakers of different languages, you must provide a way for readers to view the page in their own language. Resources are solution. The resource file has same syntax as a config file.

- [How do resources work?](#pages~Resources)
- [Example: Resources](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/localization-resources)

---

### Directory: source

This directory contains a business logic of your application. The source file can contain functions or objects which can be exported and used in each part of application.

- [Example: Source](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/framework-business-logic-source)

---

### Directory: packages

This directory contains packages. The package is a file which contains more files packed in one package file. The package behaves like a module (is same as module).

- [How do packages work?](#pages~Packages)

---

### Directory: tests

Test directory contains scripts for assertion testing. In assertion test you can test e.g. controller routing.

- [Example: Tests](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/assertion-testing)

---

### Directory: tmp

This directory is a temporary directory and contains temporary files. The framework stores some compiled files, internal cache and form uploads into this directory.

---

### Directory: views

This directory contains views and layouts.

---

### Directory: workers

This directory contains workers. The worker creates a new independent thread, which it can communicate with framework through events.

- [Example: Workers](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/workers)
- [Example: Generating sitemap with the Worker](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/xml-sitemap-workers)

> __The Package__ is same as the total.js module, but the Package can contains multiple files in the one package file. ```plain Initialization: Modules --> Packages --> Models --> Definitions --> Controllers ``` __More informations__ - The package is the plain text file with `.package` extension. - The framework automatically unpacks the package into the temporary directory and loads. - All packages are stored in `your-app/packages/` directory. - `index.js` is the main file of the package and has __the same structure as the module__. - `exports.install` is executed automatically and one time. - Views can be mapped from the package easily: `controller.view('@packagename/myview')` - Views and static files must be mapped. - You can create unlimited count of packages. - The package can be injected from the URL address - [Download packages](https://github.com/totaljs/modules) `PACKAGE == MODULE with dependencies` --- ## How to create the package? The framework binary contains command `-package` which can create the package file from some directory. Firstly is needed install the framework from NPM as __global__ modul because of binary/executable file. The __binary__/executable name is `$ totalpackage`. ### Create the own package Firstly we must create the module: Open terminal: ```bash mkdir hello-world-package-directory cd hello-world-package ``` __1. Create__ `hello-world-package-directory/index.js`: ```javascript exports.id = 'helloworld'; exports.install = function() { console.log('Hello from the package!'); // Routing: F.route('/hello-world/', view_greeting); // A static file mapping: F.map('/myview.js', '@helloworld/myview.js'); }; function view_greeting() { // IMPORTANT: for the view will be used a layout out of this package. // or create your own this.layout('@helloworld/layout') this.view('@helloworld/myview'); } ``` __2. Create__ `hello-world-package-directory/myview.html`: ```html
Hello from the package
``` __3. Create__ `hello-world-package-directory/myview.js`: ```javascript alert('Hello world!'); ``` __3. Open terminal:__ ```bash cd hello-world-package-directory totalpackage create helloworld.package ``` The binary/executable creates the file `my-package.package` in the current directory. Copy the file into the `my-total-js-app/packages` and run the framework. The framework automatically unpacks the content of the package file into the temporary directory and it executes `index.js` as main file. Open: `http://127.0.0.1:8000/hello-world/` in your browser.

pages.body: The resource file is the simple KEY/VALUE dictionary and you can store into it everything. Resources are simple and effective. On the resources is builded [localization](#pages~Localization). - The resource is the plain text file with `.resource` extension. - Framework loads each resource when is needed. - You can create unlimited count of resources. - Resources are readonly. - Resources are cached (in release mode) for 20 minutes. - Resources are used for validation. [Example](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/validation) ## Examples - [Example: Localization](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/localization-resources) - [Example: Schema validation](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/framework-schema-validation) - [Example: Validation](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/validation) - [Example: Custom validation](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/validation-custom) --- ## The definition ### resources/default.resource ```plain key1 : value1 // comment key2 : value2 key3 : with the tag ``` ### resources/en.resource ```plain key1 : value1-en // comment key2 : value2-en key3 : with the tag-en ``` ### resources/de.resource ```plain key1 : value1-de // comment key2 : value2-de key3 : with the tag-de ``` ## Reading values from resources - [Documentation: RESOURCE()](#api~global~RESOURCE) - [Documentation: framework.resource()](#api~Framework~framework.resource) - [Documentation: controller.resource()](#api~FrameworkController~controller.resource) ```javascript console.log(RESOURCE('key1')); console.log(framework.resource('key1')); // value1 console.log(RESOURCE('en', 'key1')); // value1-en console.log(RESOURCE('de', 'key1')); // value1-de ``` ### View engine ```html @{resource('key3')} @{!resource('key3')} @{resource('en', 'key3')} @{!resource('en', 'key3')} @{resource('de', 'key3')} @{!resource('de', 'key3')} ```

`Views` can render HTML. You can render "view" in "view" and "view" is rendered into the layout at the end. The view engine supports conditions, loops, sections, helpers and inline helpers. --- __More informations__ - View is the plain HTML file with `.html` extension. - __IMPORTANT:__ Server tags are represented as `@{keyword}` (encoded) tag and `@{!keyword}` (raw) tag. - Views are synchronous. - Views are compiled into the function. - All views (HTML) are minimized under the compilation (total.js saves memory). - The layout is rendered at the last (if it's not disabled). - You can render some view into the string. - The default layout filename is `layout.html`, in older versions it has been `_layout.html`. - The char `~` maps the current path of the view into the views root directory - [View properties and methods](#api~FrameworkViews) --- ### Examples Most [examples](https://github.com/totaljs/examples) contain views. - [Example: Views](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views) - [Example: Views with XHR](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-xhr) - [Example: Views places and sections](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-place-sections) - [Example: Views meta](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-meta) - [Example: Views inline JavaScript compress](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-javascript-compress) - [Example: Views head](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-head) - [Example: Views custom helper](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/views-custom-helper) --- ## Repository vs. Model Exist many ways how to send some values between controllers and views. You can transfer data between the controller and the view via `controller.repository` or `controller.view('name', model)`. ```javascript exports.install = function(framework, name) { framework.route('/', view_homepage); }; function view_homepage() { var self = this; self.repository.firstname = 'Peter'; self.view('my-view', { firstname: 'Lucia' }); } ``` A picture describes the behaviour of variables: ![Repository vs. model](resources/viewengine-repository-vs-model.png) ```html

My View

Get the value from the repository: @{repository.firstname}
Get the value from the model: @{model.firstname}
@{view('partial-view-1', model)}
@{view('partial-view-2')}
``` ## Defining the layout You can create unlimited layouts and customize them according to the name. The layout is same as the view but only one different is tag `@{body}`. Into this tag is rendered the view. ### The layout example ```html @{meta} @{head} @{css('default.css')} @{js('default.js')} @{favicon('favicon.ico')}
@{section('panel')} @{body}
@{view('footer')} ``` Read more about [view engine tags](#api~FrameworkViews). --- ## Defining the view You can create unlimited views. ### Example ```html @{meta('Title', 'Description (optional)', 'Keywords (optional)')}
Hello World!
@{view('products', [{ name: 'A', price: 23.32 }, { name: 'B', price: 32.10 }])} @{view('users', model)} @{view('products', [{ name: 'A', price: 23.32 }, { name: 'B', price: 32.10 }, { name: 'C', price: 15.22 }])} ``` ## Escaping The view engine automatically escape HTML entities. Tag with `@{!` renders the raw value. ```html @{repository.tag = 'Hello World'}
ESCAPED: @{repository.tag}
RAW: @{!repository.tag}
``` __Output__: ```html
ESCAPED: Hello <b>World</b>
RAW: Hello World
``` ## Conditions ```html @{if user === null}
sign in
@{else}
sign up
@{fi}

@{if model.name === 'Peter'} @{if model.name === 'Lucia'}
Here is Lucia.
@{else}
Here is Peter.
@{fi} @{fi}

@{if model.name !== 'Peter'}
Here is @{model.name}
@{fi} ``` ## Looping ```html @{foreach m in [1, 2, 3, 4]}
@{m}, index: @{index}
@{end}

@{foreach property in model}
@{index}
@{property.name}
@{property.age.format('### ###')}
@{end} ``` ## Sections __View__: ```html @{section footer}
THIS IS FOOTER FROM THE VIEW
@{end}

Homepage


``` __Layout__: ```html .... .... @{body} .... .... @{section('footer')} .... .... ``` __Output__: ```html .... ....

Homepage


.... ....
THIS IS FOOTER FROM THE VIEW
.... .... ``` ## Assignment values __SUPPORTS ONLY:__ repository, model, user, session, global, get, post and config. ```html @{repository.name = 'Peter'}

@{repository.name}

``` __Output__: ```html

Peter

``` ## Defining helpers ```javascript framework.helpers.custom = function(str, num) { // this === controller return str + ' = ' + num; }; ``` ```html @{custom('Peter', 25)} ``` ## Defining inline helpers The inline helper must by defined in the view. ```html @{helper address(street, city)

Address

@{street}
@{city}

@{end}
Address 1
@{address('Baker street 3', 'Wien')}
Address 2
@{address('Galvaniho 3', 'Bratislava')} ``` ## Defining custom 3rd compilers The view engine supports custom 3rd compilers. [How to write a connection to 3rd compiler?](#api~Framework~framework.onCompileView) ```html

HANDLEBARS

@{compile handlebars}

Handlebars: {{ title }}

{{ body }}

@{end}

JADE

@{compile jade} h3 View engine p Total.js is amazing! @{end} ``` ## Date feature `date` function compares the current date with date in the argument. ```html @{if date('>', '2015-01-01') && date('<', '2015-01-10 12:00')}
! Happy new year !
@{fi} @{viewToggle(date('=', '2014-08-08'), 'important-partial-view')} ``` ## Defining views in sub-directories The default controller `default.js` includes views from the default views directory `/views`. To modify this behaviour, rename the controller's filename (e.g: `controllers/site.js`) to match a directory of the same name under views (e.g: `views/site/`). The views contained within the `site` directory would be displayed. __IMPORTANT__: char `~` is very important for mapping path of views, because `~index` is still routed into the `/views/index.html`. --- ## Localization The framework automatically translates `@(text)` when compiling the views. - [How does localization work?](#pages~Localization) ```html @{meta('@(My custom title)', '@(Description to translate)')}

@(Hello world)

@(Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur ...)

@(#T-3403403030)

@(#T34930203922)

``` ## Auto binding values ![Auto binding values](resources/viewengine-binding.png) __Controller__: ```javascript function view_contactform() { this.view('contactform', { Email: '@', Name: 'Anoym' }); }; ``` __View__: ```html Email: @{text('Email')} Name: @{text('Name')} ``` __Output__: ```html Email: Name: ``` --- [Download the syntax highlighter for Sublime Text 3](#pages~Developer%20tools)

The localization is big tool for multilingual websites. - The framework translates views at time of compilation. - Each translated view is stored into the memory. - For generating translations is needed `total` (An executable file). - The text for translate is wrapped with `@()` tag (it will be a default text). - [Documentation: F.translate()](#api~Framework~framework.translate) - For setting the language for the current request use [F.onLocate()](#api~Framework~framework.onLocate) delegate __IMPORTANT__: - The localized text doesn't start with `#sometext` because for the framework is `sometext` key and the framework reads this key directly from the resource file. --- ## Full example ### First step You must install `total.js` as global module from NPM: ```bash $ sudo npm install -g total.js ``` ### Implementation The controller: ```javascript exports.install = function() { F.route('/', view_index); }; function view_index() { var self = this; // Set the language according to the query parameter in URI: self.language = self.query.language || ''; // or accoding to the request header: Accept-Language // self.language = self.req.language; self.view('index'); } ``` The view: ```html @{meta('@(Title)')}

@(Hello world!)

@(total.js is web application framework for node.js)

@(#message) or @(#T80818744) is same as @(Title) (read below)
``` ### Create resource __1.__ Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ cd myapp $ total --translate ``` The Total Application finds all texts for translation and creates the resource file `translate.resource` for translation. The keys are numbers in the resource file because the framework saves the performance and memory (saves RAM). ```html // Total.js translation file // Created: 2014-12-18 10:32 // index.html T80818744 : Title T-52966915 : Hello world! T-1870230665 : total.js is web application framework for node.js // IMPORTANT: This line was created manually message : Direct reading ``` __2.__ I copy the content from `translate.resource` to the new resource: `/resources/sk.resource` and I translate it, e.g.: ```html // Total.js translation file // Created: 2014-12-18 10:32 // index.html T80818744 : Titulok T-52966915 : Ahoj svet! T-1870230665 : total.js je webový framework pre node.js // IMPORTANT: This line was created manually message : Priame čítanie ``` ### Run `http://127.0.0.1:8000` ```html ... ... Title ... ...

Hello world!

total.js is web application framework for node.js

Direct reading or Title is same as Title (read below)
... ... ``` `http://127.0.0.1:8000/?language=sk` ```html ... ... Titulok ... ...

Ahoj svet!

total.js je webový framework pre node.js

Priame čítanie or Titulok is same as Titulok (read below)
... ... ``` ## Translation tools If you installed __total.js__ from NPM as global module then you have available translation tools. ### Tracking of new changes The command `-diff` creates the resource file with changes between two resources (newest texts and removed texts). Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ cd myapp $ total -diff en.resource de.resource ``` ### Translating of text files Content of __my-translation.txt__: ``` Hello World! I help you My name is Peter. Total.js is the web application framework ``` Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ total --translate my-translation.txt ``` ### Translate custom phrase Open terminal or command-line: ```bash $ cd myapp $ total --translate "Hello World" ``` Output: ``` T-862545276 : Hello World ```

> total.js is doing the dirty job for you. Its core has implemented good tools to improve development and rendering web site for all web browsers.

## Release mode

- The framework sets reasonable HTTP cache for the static files (IMG, JS, CSS).
- The framework clears used resources in a time loop.
- The release mode returns highly rated content.

![Page speed](resources/html-pagespeed.png)

---

### HTML

- All comments are removed from the HTML.
- The HTML code is minified under compilation.

![HTML output](resources/html-sourcecode.gif)

---

### CSS

- All CSS code is minified `framework.config['allow-compile-css']`
- CSS supports - auto vendor prefixes - [Example: auto-vendor-prefixes](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/css-auto-vendor-prefixes).
- You can disable `auto-vendor-prefixes` - remove comment from the CSS: `/*auto*/`
- Inline styles in the HTML `<style type="text/css">`... are compiled and minified.
- You can rewrite built-in compilation - [SASS example](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/external-compile-sass).
- If the filename contains `.min` then it won't be compiled and minified.
- All minified styles are stored in `/tmp/` directory.

__CSS - Auto vendor prefixes__:

```css
/*auto*/

.animate { animation: myfirst 5s; }

@keyframes myfirst
{
    from { background: red; }
    to { background: yellow; }
}
```

__Output__:

```css
.animate{animation:myfirst 5s;-webkit-animation:myfirst 5s;-moz-animation:myfirst 5s;-o-animation:myfirst 5s;}@keyframes myfirst{from{background:red;}to{background:yellow;}}@-webkit-keyframes myfirst{from{background:red;}to{background:yellow;}}@-moz-keyframes myfirst{from{background:red;}to{background:yellow;}}@-o-keyframes myfirst{from{background:red;}to{background:yellow;}}
```

### JavaScript

- All JavaScript code is minified `framework.config['allow-compile-js']`
- Inline JavaScripts in the HTML `<script type="text/javascript">` ... are minified.
- You can rewrite built-in minification - [Example: Uglify](https://github.com/totaljs/examples/tree/master/external-compile-uglifyjs).
- If the filename contains `.min` then it won't be minified.
- All minified scripts are stored in `/tmp/` directory.

```javascript
$(document).ready(function() {
    alert('WELCOME');
});
```

__Output__:

```javascript
$(document).ready(function(){alert('WELCOME');});
```

## Bonus

`total` (`+v1.8.0`) binary supports minifying HTML, JS and CSS files. You can minify each HTML, CSS or JS file outside of total.js project.

__Example__:

```bash
$ total --minify example.html
```

__Output:__ example.min.html

```bash
$ total --minify example.js
```

__Output:__ example.min.js

```bash
$ total --minify example.css
```

__Output:__ example.min.css

## Websocket connection is disconnected after 1 minute

Certainly you use __NGINX__. The problem is in `proxy_read_timeout`:
<http://nginx.org/en/docs/http/ngx_http_proxy_module.html#proxy_read_timeout>

---

## Synchronous programming not working

Probably you run node application without `--harmony` argument (__node +v0.11__).

```bash
$ node --harmony my-application.js
```

---

## Too many open files

If the framework throws `Too many open files` exception then we must enable [default-maximum-file-descriptors](#api~FrameworkConfiguration~default-maximum-file-descriptors) or increase the system limit via terminal `$ ulimit -v unlimited`.

```text
// The framework opens max. 10 files together and waits while they are not closed.
default-maximum-file-descriptors        : 10
```
